content.description: Do you love traversing? Do you love doing doing 20-25 moves? Then this is the problem for you.
content.location: Start on the extension start hold on the left end of the face under the small overhung section. Traverse right along the entire face of the boulder around the blunt arete finishing the same as One-Two Put on Your Shoes.

content.description: One of the extensions to the original 3 into the same topout as Artful Deception
content.location: Start towards the left side of the tall front face, sitting below the left facing corner created by the overhanging bulge of Governor's Ball.  Traverse right into Artful Deception, finishing on that problem.

content.description: A smooth easy warmup arete to walk up and get the blood flowing.
content.location: Located in the right corner of the boulder before the right face. Start at the bottom of the clear arete and follow it up through the topout.

content.description: A fun techy problem traversing along the right end of the wall into an easy topout.
content.location: Start sitting, hands on incuts down and left from the blunt prow, the same as the direct version of Luau. Once up to the good flake on the prow, traverse left around the blunt arete using the scoopy sidepull and feeding into The Nest to topout.

content.description: Layback and jam your way up the crack
content.location: Right side of the New Beach Wall.

content.description: Squat start on crimps, move left hand up to hold on right side of the crack, reach out right to undercling crimp, stand up on the feet, FA beta used  a toe hook out left near the start crimps, cross left hand over and up to a good edge near the top of the boulder, (big move up to the same edge with the right hand works also) match it and move up through one more good edge to an easy topout. The problem eliminates the left side of the crack in order to make use of the clean face to the right.
content.location: Right side of the New Beach Wall, sharing part of the crack with Pineapple Jam.

content.description: An easy warmup problem working through some good holds and slabby feet.
content.location: Start on 2 good crimp ledges around chest height with good feet below. Make a move up to the large ledge and topout from there.

content.description: Fantastic climb going up the right blunt arete of the boulder working through some fun movement into an easy sloped topout.Link showing the FA with the full traverse (Thanks Dana) youtu.be/AUEgrvo7Jbk?t=23
content.location: Most ascents now use various direct starts (grade doesn't really change much for either), but the official FA started on the left side of the face, standing at the right facing corner made by the overhanging bulge and traverses the wall along the juggy horizontals to the right until you get to the blunt arete. Make use of the flakes on each side of the arete to gain a high sidepull with your right and topout directly above with a cool mantle. The full traverse start maybe adds a half a grade for additional pump. Another variation "Group Hug" starts the traverse using the lower horizontal.

content.description: Sit start with left hand in slot and right on large flat edge with large feet below. Move up to a good edge at the edge of the small overhang and from there you can trend right through slopers to move up the right arete. After moving up through the slopers, get a high foot and move up to the large pinch rail, match it then rock over onto the easier terrain and top out.
content.location: Head around the left side of the New Beach and back ~20/30' (like you were heading to the Big 40 wall) and you will see the mini cave this route climbs out of.. It's the same formation as the rest of New Beach, but somewhat separated from the other routes by broken down rock.

content.description: Compress the far left obvious buldge. (Directly left of the jug rails). Direct top out
Sit start on the big jug below and a little right of the blunt arete. Traverse right, staying low and making use of the low horizontal, then angle up into Nest and finish that climb.
content.protection: 2-3 pads, the landing is a bit rocky.

content.description: Crimp sit start left of luaua and finish directly up on crimps and difficult mantle

Stand/squat start on good slopers at the lip of the boulder. Utilizing a large foot ledge traverse right through the lip of the boulder using good slopers and positive crimps. Once at the last good hold before the right arete, reach back past the lip with the left for a good sidepull, work your feet up and rock over the lip.
content.protection: 1-2 pads, it traverses past a tree but is low to the ground
content.location: Left side of the New Beach wall, directly to the left of Governors Ball. Clearly visible as you break off the approach trail to the boulder.

content.description: Sit start in the seam in front of the tree, with good feet pull onto the wall and make one long reach to a good edge at the lip. Traverse a move or two to the right and finish by rocking over using a left hand sidepull just over the lip, just as for the traverse.
content.location: On the small wall directly left of Governors Ball, easily visible as you walk up to the New Beach wall from the approach trail.

content.description: The clear center climb in the middle of the boulder face with great holds and a fairly blank topout.
content.location: Squat start on the clear ledge in the middle of the wall and work your way up into a good rail traversing right to the top and escaping right along the lip until you can press out the mantel as for Luau.

content.description: Another easy line to hang on some jug rails and stretch your way for a good warmup.
content.location: Located on the right corner of the right face. Start standing on the small ledge at the blunt arete. Move into the deep rail following it left into the topout.

content.description: Very convenient bouldering ledge right off the trail a few minutes from parking, with excellent rock quality and a nice setting. This is a great spot to warm up on the way back to the bouldering near the southern end of the pond or as a destination in itself.
